Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218, Section 19.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186,.proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.

Pfrommer v. United Structures of Am., In.raw_text: Pfrommer v. United Structures of Am., Inc., 37 Mass. App. Ct. 400 (1994)
Pfrommer v. United Structures of Am., In.proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.
Pfrommer v. United Structures of Am., In.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Pfrommer v. United Structures of Am., Inc. concerns public bidding, actions of the Department of Labor and Industries, and criticism of government attorneys. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, or any covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address a landlord’s duty to remedy noise caused by other tenants. Accordingly, it cannot be used as authority for the stated quiet enjoyment proposition.
Pfrommer v. United Structures of Am., In.relevant_excerpt: The ruling by the Department of Labor and Industries (DOLI) was clear, concise, and correct: There was no need to rebid, as the “public interest” was not adversely affected, and “the contract should [have been] awarded to Petricca,” the entity whose bid had not been deemed informal and was lower than the Highway Department’s engineer’s estimate. Instead, the department chose to flout the DOLI determination and to rebid the project.

McKenna v. Begin, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 171.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 171 (1982)
McKenna v. Begin, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 171.proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.
McKenna v. Begin, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 171.support_reasoning: The opinion in McKenna v. Begin does not address landlord-tenant law, noise disturbances, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It concerns alleged misrepresentation and building code violations in the sale of an apartment building between buyer, seller, and broker, and the court analyzes misrepresentation, c. 93A, and rescission/mutual mistake. There is no discussion of a landlord’s duty to remedy tenant-caused noise or any breach of quiet enjoyment, so it does not support the stated proposition.
McKenna v. Begin, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 171.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff buyer (Lawton) brought an action against the defendant seller (Dracousis) and the defendant broker (Godin), alleging that they had induced him to buy Dracousis’ property by representing that there were no existing State building code violations affecting the building in dispute, when, in fact, there were. Lawton sought damages for deceit and violations of G. L. c. 93A, as well as rescission of the sale.… [T]he trial judge found that neither Dracousis nor Godin had deceived Lawton and entered a judgment in their favor.”

Woods v. Lancet, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 743 (.proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.
Woods v. Lancet, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 743 (.support_reasoning: The decision is a summary process/waiver-of-notice case about a landlord evicting a tenant for causing disturbances; it does not discuss Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, nor the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion analyzes lease violations, termination, waiver by acceptance of rent, and procedural/jurisdictional issues, but nowhere addresses a landlord’s duty to remedy noise from other tenants or any breach of quiet enjoyment claim. Using this case to support a tenant’s quiet enjoyment/noise theory would therefore be inaccurate.
Woods v. Lancet, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 743 (.relevant_excerpt: The trial judge found that the tenant violated the following paragraphs of the lease: 8-a, which required him to “live in a peaceful way, respecting the rights of his neighbors to privacy and quiet,” 10-2, which provided that the lease could be terminated by the landlord for the “[r]easonable likelihood of serious repeated interference with the rights of other tenants,” and 10-5, which provided that it could also be terminated for the tenant’s “[c]reation or maintenance of a serious threat to the health or safety of other tenants.”

Fontaine v. Ebian Corp., 4 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: This is a petition for an assessment of damages under G. L. c. 79, § 14, following the taking by eminent domain of the plaintiff’s land on June 19, 1968. The property in question consisted of two parcels of vacant land located in New Bedford... A jury returned a verdict for the plaintiff... The defendant raises only one question in regard to the first trial... [t]hose sections (read together) provided that a verdict could be set aside and a new trial ordered only upon a motion in writing...

Moerman v. Boston Housing Auth., 13 Mass.relevant_excerpt: The judge correctly determined that Dauphinais’s claim to the land was by adverse possession which “can be acquired only by proof of nonpermissive use which is actual, open, notorious, exclusive and adverse for twenty years.” Ryan v. Stavros, 348 Mass. 251, 262 (1964).

Collins, 308 Mass. 236 (1941).proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.
Staples v. Collins, 308 Mass. 236 (1941).case_name: Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Co. v. Mayor of Fall River
Staples v. Collins, 308 Mass. 236 (1941).support_reasoning: The opinion in Staples v. Collins involves municipal contracting authority between a school committee and a mayor over a school transportation contract. It does not concern landlord–tenant law, Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, or any covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address noise disturbances or a landlord’s duty to control other tenants. Therefore, it does not support the claimed proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Staples v. Collins, 308 Mass. 236 (1941).relevant_excerpt:
This petition is brought to compel the mayor of Fall River to approve a contract involving more than $500 for the furnishing of transportation of school children for a period of three years. The school committee awarded the contract to the petitioner... The mayor still refuses to approve.
...
Inasmuch as we hold that the contract in question required the approval of the mayor under G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 43, § 29, and that his approval was not a merely perfunctory matter but involved the exercise of his own independent judgment... there is no ground on which the court can intervene to compel him to take further action.

Park Drive Realty Corp. v. Cooper, 416 M.proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.
Park Drive Realty Corp. v. Cooper, 416 M.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Flood v. Southland Corp., not Park Drive Realty Corp. v. Cooper, and it concerns premises liability and foreseeability of third-party criminal acts, not a landlord’s statutory or common-law duty under G.L. c. 186, § 14, or a covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not discuss noise disturbances between tenants, landlord obligations to address them, or any breach of quiet enjoyment theory. Therefore it does not support the claimed proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment for failure to address tenant-caused noise.
Park Drive Realty Corp. v. Cooper, 416 M.relevant_excerpt: “Southland owed a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff … to prevent injury by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional (Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452 [1969]). Southland argues, however, that it owed no duty to the plaintiff in this case because the risk that led to the plaintiff's injury was not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant. Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646 (1990).”

Kriegel v. Lexington Partners, LLC, 71 M.raw_text: Kriegel v. Lexington Partners, LLC, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 552 (2008)
Kriegel v. Lexington Partners, LLC, 71 M.proposition: Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment - Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14, and relevant case law, Defendant has breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by failing to take reasonable steps to address and remedy the ongoing noise disturbances caused by other tenants.
Kriegel v. Lexington Partners, LLC, 71 M.case_name: Reliance Insurance v. City of Boston
Kriegel v. Lexington Partners, LLC, 71 M.support_reasoning: This case concerns suretyship, anti-assignment clauses, and subrogation rights in a public construction contract dispute, not landlord–tenant law or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not cite or interpret Mass. G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address a landlord’s duty to remedy noise disturbances by other tenants. Using this opinion to support a quiet-enjoyment breach theory in a residential or commercial tenancy context would therefore be inaccurate.
Kriegel v. Lexington Partners, LLC, 71 M.relevant_excerpt: "We leave for another day the interesting question whether an effective contractual bar against subrogation in a public construction context might, in light of the statute requiring the provision of surety bonds, be unenforceable as violative of public policy. Suffice it to say that in the present case, as in Handex, the parties knew full well that the surety would seek to recoup any losses by exercising its right of subrogation... It follows that the anti-assignment clauses in the general contract cannot reasonably be construed to affect subrogation rights under the payment bond."
